Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Program statement
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents' needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation A few days ago, a youth was resting in their room and a staff
member entered the room, kissed the youth's cheek and caressed
the youth's hair. The staff member has been put on paid leave.
Investigation Interviews:
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on
December 23, 2024, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. A
translator was used for this interview. Youth A reported she
knows why she is being interviewed and stated that Staff 1 has
good intentions. When asked to explain more, Youth A reported
about four weeks ago, Staff 1 came into her room, touched her
hair, and kissed her on her face near her ear. She reported Staff 1
had come into her room to wake her up to do chores. Youth A
reported she was lying in bed when Staff 1 came into her room.
She reported the door was closed and that Staff 1 was talking to
her in English, which she did not understand, then touched her
hair and kissed her face by her ear. Youth A reported she does
not know why Staff 1 did this and believes she was trying to be
more like a mother figure to her. She reported she heard Staff 2
coming to check in and Staff 1 rushed out of the room. Youth A
reported that staff are not allowed in the youth’s bedrooms with
the door closed. Youth A reported about two weeks ago Staff 1
touched her hair in her room to wake her up to go to therapy. She
reported Staff 2 saw Staff 1 come into Youth A’s room and asked
Youth A what happened. Youth A stated that she did not make it a
big deal but did state Staff 1 had made her feel uncomfortable.
She reported she shared a room with Youth B, but Youth B was
always sleeping so she did not see any of this happen. Youth A
reported she does not want Staff 1 to get in trouble.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the main agency
building on December 30, 2024, in collaboration with MDHHS
Worker. Staff 1 reported she has been working at the facility
2

since September 2024. She reported she was aware of the
allegations. Staff 1 reported a few days ago, Youth A did not want
to go to group therapy due to not feeling well, which is unlike
Youth A to refuse to go. She reported she checked in on Youth A
in Youth A’s bedroom. Staff 1 reported she does not believe she
propped the bedroom door open when she went in. She reported
she went into the room to ensure Youth A did not need anything
and to physically check on her wellbeing. Staff 1 reported she
stood next to Youth A’s bed and brushed Youth A’s hair out of
Youth A’s face with her hand to check her face. She reported she
brushed Youth A’s hair off her face because she wanted to make
sure she was okay and was not crying. When asked if Staff 1 had
kissed Youth A on her head or near her ear, Staff 1 reported “I do
not think so.” Staff 1 was asked to explain more of the statement,
“I do not think so”, she reported she could not remember if she
had kissed her or not. When asked if she had kissed other
children in the home, she reported she had kissed Youth B on the
head before to comfort her. Staff 1 explained there was a day
when Youth B was struggling with her mental health and was
attempting to self-harm. She reported she went to console Youth
B who was crying by patting her on her back and comforted her by
telling her that she was cared for. Staff 1 reported she asked
Youth B if she could kiss her on her head and Youth B gave her
permission. She reported she kissed her on her head like she
would do her own children to show Youth B she is cared for. Staff
1 reported the kiss was not in a sexual manner. Staff 1 was asked
if kissing a youth at the facility is allowed to be done and she
reported she does not believe so. She reported she knows within
her training from the facility, staff are to ask the youth if it is okay
to be touched and that side hugs are only allowed. Staff 1
acknowledged that she never asked Youth A if she could move
her hair, and she may have crossed a professional boundary with
Youth B by kissing her on the head for comfort. She was asked if
Youth A and Youth B would understand her when she talked to
them since their primary language is not English and she reported
they do understand her. Staff 1 was asked about the policy on
going into the youth’s bedrooms and shutting the door, she
reported staff are not supposed to go into the youth’s bedrooms
unless it is necessary. Staff 1 reported if staff are to go into a
bedroom the door should be propped open but believes she did
not remember doing that when Youth A was sick in her room.
Youth B was interviewed face to face at the facility on
December 30, 2024, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker.
Case Manager translated for Youth B. Youth B reported she is
treated well at the facility and did not have any concerns. When
3

asked if staff are allowed to go into the youth’s bedrooms, she
reported they are not supposed to go into the bedrooms. She
reported the only time she remembers staff going into her
bedroom was when she was trying to harm herself. Youth B
reported she does share a room with Youth A but does not
remember Staff 1 ever coming into their room for Youth A. She
reported Staff 1 is one of her favorite staff and cares for the youth.
Youth B reported Staff 1 will treat her like a daughter, console her
when she is sad, and works on practicing English with her. She
denied Staff 1 ever kissing her and reported Staff 1 will give her a
hug only when Youth B asks for a hug. Youth B reported all staff
give her hugs as she is the one to ask for hugs from them.
Staff 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
December 30, 2024, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker.
Staff 2 reported she works a lot with Staff 1 and noted Staff 1
works well with the youth. When asked if staff can go into youth’s
bedrooms, she reported staff should only go into a youth’s
bedroom on rare occasions such as if there is a safety concern.
Staff 2 reported staff are trained not to go into the youth’s
bedrooms with the door closed because of safety concerns this
can create and there are no cameras in the bedroom. She
reported she witnessed Staff 1 go into a youth’s bedroom, she
could not remember who, to provide them medicine, and Staff 2
had a conversation with Staff 1 to not do this due to safety
concerns. Staff 2 reported Youth A disclosed the concerns to her
about boundary issues Staff 1 had with her touching her hair and
kissing her. She reported staff are not allowed to touch the youth
unless asked, such as a side hug, and should never kiss a youth.
Staff 2 reported she never witnessed Staff 1 touch or kiss a youth.
Staff 2 reported these concerns to Supervisor.
Supervisor was interviewed face to face at the facility on
December 30, 2024, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker.
Supervisor reported there had been no concerns with Staff 1 until
this reported allegation. She reported staff are trained that they
should never fully go into a youth’s bedroom with the door closed.
Supervisor reported Staff 1 is motherly with the youth, but she has
never witnessed or heard of Staff 1 crossing professional
boundaries with the youth.
Case Manager was interviewed face to face at the facility on
December 23, 2024, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker.
Case Manager reported that Youth A disclosed to her the
concerns of Staff 1 touching her hair and crossing boundary lines.
She reported Youth A stated she did not want Staff 1 to get in
4

trouble over this and it may be a misunderstanding since she sees
Youth A as a daughter. Case Manager reported Staff 1 is very
“motherly” with the youth and wants to treat them like her own
children. She reported there had been no concerns with Staff 1
before this. Case Manager reported staff are not supposed to be
going into the youth’s rooms. She reported she did speak to
Supervisor about these concerns.
Documents Reviewed:
- Staff 1 Human Resource File- Staff 1 has had no
disciplinary actions within her Human Resource File. Staff 1
is up to date on all required trainings and signed the code
of conduct policy on 09/19/2024.
- Facility Code of Conduct Policy- Within the Staff Code of
Conduct policy it notes, “Staff must confine their
interactions and/or relationship with children, their family,
and their sponsors to those activities which fall within the
scope of their staff’s job duties.”
- Bethany Christian Services Physical Contact
Guidelines last updated 07/11/2023- This policy notes
explains staff boundary’s regarding touch when working
with youth in the programing. The policy explains that all
residents and staff have the right to request, accept, or
deny physical touch. It notes, “all staff shall collaborate to
teach residents appropriate, healthy touch in order to
promote positive attachments, reduce anxiety, and increase
sense of self-worth.” It also notes, “In order to support a
resident’s need for safety and provide protection related to
potential allegations of inappropriate touch, all forms of
touch should be done in the presence of others and not in
isolated situations.” The policy notes, “the following types of
touch are prohibited: any type of touch, comment, or
gesture that is or could be perceived as sexual in nature;
kissing.”
- Bethany Christian Services Staff Conduct and
Expectations Policy last updated 03/17/22- This policy is
in place for all residential programing Bethany Christian
Services has in place. This policy notes: “Staff are
expected to be positive role models for residents. Staff shall
maintain appropriate boundaries with residents.”
Analysis The facility is found in non-compliance of Staff 1 following the
Physical Contact Guideline policy as she reported in her interview
to kissing Youth B on the head and touching Youth A’s hair
without her permission.
Technical Assistance:
5

Technical assistance was offered to create a policy or procedure
for staff to have a clear understanding about being allowed in a
youth’s room with the door shut.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established
SIR 2024C0001040SI dated 02/15/24 CAP approved 03/08/24
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
